>How can someone like that have free will if you KNOW its going to occur?
As far as I know, by default we have free will (the Bible makes it sound like God never wanted stuff like Eve taking the fruit, or for humanity to be tainted so that He needed to flood it during Noah's time to purge it), but God can override it when He wants to. In Exodus 7-8, it's written multiple times that the Lord hardened Pharaoh's, so that Pharaoh wouldn't go along with what Moses said (first example is Exodus 7:3 - "And I will harden Pharaoh's heart, and multiply my signs and my wonders in the land of Egypt.").

So my two takeaways is that God wasn't always omnipotent about everything that would happen in the future (I mean this not in the sense that He wasn't capable of it, just that He for some reason chose not to use that power 100% of the time, hence Him regretting certain things early on in Genesis, but then He used it for other moments like foretelling incidents involving Jesus, or Revelations), and other times He will use His power to control people and override free will, like with Pharaoh. I think this is the case with Judas as well in your example.

I will say this, which might not make it sound any better for people to accept, but with the context of Peter denying Jesus also being "set in stone", I think that the actual acts are what the person would've thought to do on their own, and God or Jesus's declarations of those actions certainly happening are a result of God not letting them change their mind after that.

I'm not too sure about that either. If I use eastern traditions as a reference point to try and understand how this could still make some sense, then I could see the original intention being something like an analogue to the eastern concept of letting go of attachment to results. Your choices are yours, but the results are what they are. Fate, God's will, karma, etc. I think the reason this general concept (expressed in one way or another) is fairly universal is because of what cultivating this kind of mindset does to a person. It eases worries, makes us feel more free to do what we feel is right without less fear, without getting discouraged as easily, and without letting it go to our heads either. It basically makes people be better and more successful versions of themselves while also becoming more humble.

I don't think calling it/viewing it as "worship" as Christians generally do is necessary, but I don't think it's necessarily is a bad thing either. At least this is more or less what I think of it right now.

>Why is religion declining
Religion has served many purposes historically, including:
>A bedrock answer for ontological and epistemological questions about the nature of reality and truth
>A bedrock answer for moral debates
>A source of comfort against impending death and an uncompassionate universe
>A source of meaning and purpose in serving a congregation's ideals
>An explanation for hard-to-explain phenomena
>An administrator of local bureaucracy and enforcer of local norms and laws
>An origin story and justification for current societal structures
>A justification for leaders' right to rule, ideologically expand, oppress and enslave, and declare war
>A local social safety net for food, shelter, education, after-school care, health-care, mental health, rehab, labor for community projects, and elder care
>An art space, employer of artists, and producer of local entertainment
>A community meeting space for socialization and romance
>A national and international ideological background promoting social trust and bonding with insiders and against outsiders

Negative feedback loops exist on most of the above. If the church shrinks a little, many of the above also get less useful, so fewer people will participate, accelerating the decline.

There isn't a single cause, but the negative feedback loop was kicked off over the last 300 years by the depletion of new frontiers to convert people, liberal socialized policies and safety nets; the airplane, train and car decimating the idea of the local community; the internet and evolution of mass-media, the horrors of world war II and the atom bomb, the end of slavery, the completion of western colonial projects, the enfranchisement of previously systemically oppressed minorities and women, the US and French revolutionary rejection of the divine rights of rulers, the scientific method, widespread photography, growth in corporate power, and competing moral thought movements including LGBT+ and social justice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I used to practice active imagination semi-regularly approximately 3 years ago. I don't practice it anymore, and I have a very good reason for that. Firstly, let's remember that this term (active imagination) originates in C. G. Jung's works.

The primary issue when reading Jung's works is that he never properly defines how to do active imagination. He states what it is, but from the works of his I've read (~7), he never gives enough detail for you to start doing it in a methodological way. And where there's no methodology outlined, how can you say you're doing it as he intended?

The idea is that you are allowing your Unconscious to produce images, symbols, narratives, etc. etc. Those details alone necessitate a specification: How do you know when you're in true contact with the Unconscious or if it's a conscious fantasy by the conscious mind?

Here's what I used to do. I would lay down on my back, and I would engage in a sort of meditation. I would hold a conscious image in mind, and wait for something to happen. What happened is that I began noticing that I would sometimes reflexively produce changes in the images through my conscious mind. In other words, my conscious mind was creating a fantasy. Now, thankfully, I had enough self-awareness to catch myself doing this during the process. I disregarded it as contact with the Unconscious. If it were truly from the Unconscious, then what would happen will catch the conscious mind off guard. I would right down the transformations in the images, but I never had an "amazing insights."

The most important thing, if you're going to do it, is to develop the mindfulness to know whether or not it's legit versus just a conscious fantasy. The conscious mind has all sorts of ways of deceiving itself, and it's important we're not fooled by those things.

Nowadays, I have dispensed with active imagination as I used to do it and only do self-hypnosis. Self-hypnosis is amazing if done properly.

Another fun simple excercise I find helpful for both children and adults is based off an old show called Mr Squiggle I loved as a kid (the man from the moon heh).

All you need is a pen (preferably two tho with diff colours) and paper. Pick one colour and close your eyes and draw a few random squiggles on the paper. Open eyes and use other colour to turn them into a drawing. It's like an interactive Rorschach test that helps you imagine stuff and also drawing is fun when you aren't trying to control it/make it look 'good'.

alright, here is an actual response beyond the retardation of /x/ and the rigid autism of /sci/ or /g/. Free energy just means that we are able to harness the energy/work that is produced by a certain reaction. For example, in the case of nuclear fusion, we are able to utilize the energy which was originally mass before molecular splicing. You do not "make" free energy, you can only make energy more free. The Universe is a closed system, but you can still harness the latent energy found in the universe and make it more "free". Tesla thought that everything exists in a frequency, which is true. If we are able to harness the energy of various things (like waves which make up the EM spectrum), we can use that energy rather than just allowing it to completely dissipate. That all being said, there are holes in our current understanding of physics, such as those present in astrophysics and quantum physics. We have yet to discover gravitrons, and we have yet to identify dark matter and energy, or an alternate theory which allows our model of the universe to make sense. I would encourage you to look into the things I've mentioned.

The ancient Lyrans were titans, standing 20 to 30 feet tall, from a planet much greater in size than ours. They were white-skinned, with blond hair, usually had blue eyes, and had a life span of around 2,000 years.
They were a warlike race that had not only developed technically, but were quite advanced in the use of spiritual power. They moved their warlike forces around the galaxy and used their great power to take control of many thousands of lesser-developed races.

Over the years the Lyran blood line was mixed with other civilizations, creating many different colors and races which spread throughout the galaxy.

Just as their race was at its highest peak of advancement, a huge destructive comet that became known as the Destroyer Comet found its way into the Lyran family of planets, and two-thirds of their race were killed.
The last fly past by the Destroyer was in 1680. If this is correct, it is likely that it is the comet we know as "The Great Comet of 1680": The first ever comet discovered by telescope.

Along with the destruction, their technology was wiped out, and they were unable to continue to exercise control over the great empire they had built. The great Lyran Empire had degenerated back to one planet with no technology to speak of.
They were barely able to survive and were faced with the task of rebuilding a civilization which once dominated thousands of other worlds.

After thousands of years, the Lyrans restored their society and again became a dominant force in the Galaxy. Pleiadian history documents that he Lyrans went through a series of civilizations over a period of several millions of years. It was their pattern to rise to power, begin to fight among themselves, and then degenerate into a primitive society and start all over again. On some occasions their wars were so brutal that it took millions of years for them to recover from the primitive state left by the destruction.

posts.name: Anonymouse
posts.com:
>>33664746
It wasn't until 387,000 B.C. that the Lyrans once again had an effect on Earth. Another war had ravaged Lyra, and many of those on the losing side had fled for safety. They travelled through the cosmos and came to Earth as a place of sanctuary.
It was peaceful here; the local humans were primitive and offered no resistance to their high technology. It was decided they would stay and build a colony.

Back home in Lyra it was discovered that a large group had fled to Earth, and ships were dispatched to come after them. Upon arriving at Earth they were disgusted and appalled to find the conditions that prevailed here. The local Earth-humans were being used as slaves and were being mistreated badly. Many were being used in experiments where they were being mated with animals, while others were being disfigured, raped, or maimed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Not only is suicide a sin, it is the sin. It is the ultimate and absolute evil, the refusal to take an interest in existence; the refusal to take the oath of loyalty to life. The man who kills a man, kills a man. The man who kills himself, kills all men; as far as he is concerned he wipes out the world. His act is worse (symbolically considered) than any rape or dynamite outrage. For it destroys all buildings: it insults all women. The thief is satisfied with diamonds; but the suicide is not: that is his crime. He cannot be bribed, even by the blazing stones of the Celestial City. The thief compliments the things he steals, if not the owner of them. But the suicide insults everything on earth by not stealing it. He defiles every flower by refusing to live for its sake. There is not a tiny creature in the cosmos at whom his death is not a sneer. When a man hangs himself on a tree, the leaves might fall off in anger and the birds fly away in fury: for each has received a personal affront. Of course there may be pathetic emotional excuses for the act. There often are for rape, and there almost always are for dynamite. But if it comes to clear ideas and the intelligent meaning of things, then there is much more rational and philosophic truth in the burial at the cross-roads and the stake driven through the body, than in Mr. Archer’s suicidal automatic machines. There is a meaning in burying the suicide apart. The man’s crime is different from other crimes—for it makes even crimes impossible.
~G. K. Chesterton

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33732929
ound is another sensory modality that lacks an easily recognized relationship to kundalini-related energetic changes, although traditional literature has linked various sound experiences with the rising kundalini (Anandamurti, 1999; Mallinson and Singleton, 2017). Sound experiences during meditation were reported by 39 participants.

Of the various options, the greatest number of participants reported hearing the sound of “crickets” (n=20, 41% of Sound responders) during meditation (Figure 7A). “Tones” (n=13, 27%) were the next most common response, followed by the sound of the “ocean” (n=11, 22%) and “ankle bells” (n=10, 20%).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33732938
Participants also specified the frequency of each of their sound responses. In order to have a general sense of how frequently participants had sound experiences, each participant’s greatest reported sound frequency was graphed. “Occasionally” (n=17, 44%) was the most common (Figure 7B). The remaining frequencies had similar rates of occurrence. “Crickets” had the greatest number of “consistently” responses during meditation (n=5, 13%).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33732948
Anandamurti (1999) proposed that meditators might hear a progressive series of sounds (first crickets, followed by ankle bells, sweet flute, gong or ocean, and finally om/aum) as they deepened their meditation and kundalini rose higher through the chakras. Among our participants, cricket sounds were reported most, which might be expected for the first sound in the sequence, since sounds associated with higher chakras would have had the kundalini also pass through the lowest chakra, with its associated cricket sound. The incidence of additional sound experiences did not follow the order of the proposed sequence. If there is relevance to this sound sequence, it is not discernable with the current available information and requires further exploration.

I was seven years old. My father had walked out two years before, and my mother drowned her sorrows in religion. Every Sunday we went to church, and every Sunday I praised God, sang the songs, took communion, and walked down to the basement with the other kids to color in pictures of the parables. I loved God, I loved Jesus, I had faith with all my heart that he/they loved me and wanted the best for me.

Then, at seven years old, I had a nightmare. There was something chasing me, something wicked and terrible. I knew if it caught me it would corrupt me, it would make me evil. And I was terrified. I ran as fast as I could, and when I could run no more, panting and crying, I crawled into a trash can to hide. I could feel it more than I could hear it, out there, relishing this moment. It lifted the lid, slowly, and then it grabbed a hold of me.

And for the first time in my life I felt alive. Free. Unshackled. I felt truly powerful. On that day, I stopped singing the songs. And I've never looked back.

posts.com: I'm not certain about the definition in a Christian context, but Aristotle used this concept a lot. Baiscally, prima materia is matter but abstract, because it has no form (i.e. essence, or specificities). It cannot exist by itself because it's only the second term in things (essence/substance). >>33723194
It depends on what you mean by "idea". From a platonic point of view ("platonic ideas"), essences exist by themselves, without their material manifestations: they are principles of the material realm. Aristotle was actually against Plato's doctrine of ideas, but still believed that essence were defined (though they didn't exist in the spiritual realm).If you want to understand this doctrine, I suggest you to read Plato's Phaedo. He never exposes this doctrine in full, but it sums it up. For example, beautiful material things are only beautiful as in so for ar they are linked to the Idea (Form/Essance) of Beauty.

The Prima Materia -is- the Quitessece/Aether, and is also connected to the Anima Mundi in western Christianity since the late middle ages.
By the way a 'Christian Hermeticism' as envisioned in that book does not exist, what does exist however is the influence Hermetism had on Christianity, during the middle ages saints like Albertus Magnus developed cosmologies based on their knowledge of arabic translations of hermetic texts (only the 'technical' kind dealing with alchemy, magic and astrology, the 'religious' kind both existed beforehand in Latin, the Ascelpius, and the Corpus Have got translated at the beginning of the Renaissance by Marsilio Ficino from Greek but it's influence never really went anywhere in the Church) and of neoplatonic ones, particularly the cosmology of Liber de Causis
Overall it's a good book, especially good as something introductory as it's a form of 'Catholic Sophiology' (Sophiology is an Eastern Orthodox movement) mixed in with more 'Occult' speech to get people who are into that get interested in becoming Catholic, but if you want to go deeper i suggest you delve into:
>Jakob Böhme (Protestant)
>Nicholas of Cusa (Catholic)
>Sergei Bulgakov (Orthodox)
And from there you can expand through studying their influences and who they influenced

posts.name: Anonymous

>>33727029
Sure,
Basically during medieval times the Aristotelian concept of the 5 elements mixed with the Neoplatonic Cosmogony and was used as the framework for why things like Astrology, Alchemy and Magic worked.
First of all Aristotle, basing himself on the philosophy that came before him, wrote that our world (planet earth) was composed of 4 Elements, but those 4 came from a single Element called Aether which Aristotle belived was the Element the 7 Classical Planets were made out of.
In Neoplatonism the Unknowable God, called One/Monad, emanates/'overflows' into Nous (meaning Intellect, but it has a more complex meaning) which you can interpret as the 'Knowable God', then the Anima Mundi (World Soul) and then from the Anima overflows material reality.
Now during medieval times those mixed together as material reality was belived to be composed of 4 unchanging elements, since the origin of our world originates from Anima Mundi that'd mean that the Anima is that 5th unchanging Element.

I took the NDE pill ~10 years ago after reading "The Holographic University" by Michael Talbot. So the only big question for me is if the experience is what it presents itself as, or is it some kind of deception or trap? I'm not sure how we'd be able to conclude either one with any degree of certainty though, so I'm very curious what all the supporting evidence and logic is for the trap theory. I'm also trying to keep my own biases in check as someone with trust issues and slightly anxious, paranoid, and pessimistic tendencies.

I'm skeptical of anyone who asserts overly specific details like archons, greys, reptilians, loosh farming, ultra sci fi machines and what not for too many reasons to get into. However, it doesn't necessarily mean they're wrong about the basic gist of things. I think most people just don't well enough understand the concept of symbolism within a holographic/fractal model of consciousness. What I mean is most people take what is experienced in altered states of mind far too literally.

What you experience when you astral project, remote view, dream, or have an NDE is almost never literally what is appears to be. Our basic 5 senses are stable and well developed. When we sense beyond that, our minds struggle to decode information into something coherent to present our awareness with, and we end up with highly subjective symbolism. This is why it's not always "a light at the end of a tunnel", but often it'll be a bridge, a boat, or a trail through a forest even. It's your mind presenting an extremely in accurate and subjective approximation of reality to your awareness.

1/2 I guess

This. I've had one experience that (for me personally) was complete confirmation that it really is possible for your consciousness to leave your body. The last time I tripped I tried meditating at the peak, and the trip instantly just "turned off". The visuals, the trippy mindfuck headspace was gone, the body load, all of it stopped instantly. The only way that could happen to me is if my consciousness had separated from my physical, mushroom-addled brain and body. Instead of meditation enhancing the trip as one might expect, the psilocin seemed to help send me into a deeper state of meditation, and this completely overrode the trip. It's difficult to describe what the experience that replaced the trip felt like, but it was joyful yet very calm and peaceful, not ecstatic or overwhelming. It just felt like absolute stillness, and all my senses could perceive were a pale golden light and a steady drone. As soon as I willed myself back to reality, the trip instantly returned as if I had just returned to my body.

Weird shit, and I'm hesitant to try and draw more conclusions about what I had experienced or attempt to explain it more. I want to go back though. It also reminds me of a story mentioned in the holographic universe book I mentioned in a previous post. Some Buddhist monk was given 900mcg of acid and all he had to say was "this is nice, but meditation is better". Now I understand exactly what he meant. That's how he was able to basically just ignore 900mcg of LSD, that's why he claimed meditation is better. Deep meditation separates your consciousness from your body, or at least turns off your senses. Which is obvious in hindsight, this is why you're supposed to focus on a single subject to the exclusion of all else. It's training you to separate from your physical senses so you can experience pure consciousness directly.

>>33724945
>isn't that sort of what you're doing by calling critical differences semantics?
I'm pointing out that what people perceive as critical differences are more often then not just different semantics or perspectives. Words are just symbols. Language is symbolic. Symbols can never perfectly represent something or have identical meaning to any two people, as each person's understanding of any given symbol is formed by unique life experiences, association, and pattern recognition.

The inherent inaccuracy of language leads to exponentially more complex language barriers as we try to create symbols for increasingly abstract concepts built upon previous symbols assumed to be understood. Similarly with perspective. It's like arguing over the color of a coin that's red on one side and blue on the other, because both parties are unwilling to look at the other side of the coin and see why the other's perspective makes sense to the other party. Now imagine an object with an infinite number of faces and an infinite number of observers. That's the nature of discussing spiritual concepts.

If I were wrong, the entire world would have formed a consensus on a single spiritual worldview a very long time ago. People view the same things differently. People describe the same things differently. This is the entire reason there are different religions. Some are more accurate than others, but they're all seeking the truth, and they're all trying to describe their perspectives on the truth. Ultimately the truth will always be whatever it is, whether we understand each other or not.

You think not being your mind or body means all that's left is awareness, meaning you think your will comes from your mind/body. It's the opposite though. Your will is influenced by your mind and body and, but your will does not come from your mind or your body.

Do you need to will your body to breath? To blink? To sweat? To digest, shed skin, heal wounds, grow hair, or produce the thousands of hormones and chemicals it produces? No. That's not your will making those things, your body does all those on its own. You're not the body.

What about your mind? Have you ever tried not to think? Have you ever got a song stuck in your head? Have you ever had real distractions pop into your head? What about habitual thought patterns you don't particular care? That's not your own will doing those things. You're not the mind either.

Your body and mind both know how to get your attention and influence your will with all kinds of nerve signals, hormones, chemicals, etc. They'll even work together some times to get your to do what they want. Anyone who's ever struggled with any kind of addiction knows what this is like.

If this doesn't make yet, then practice meditating for a few day. You don't even have to get good at it at all. The challenge in the beginning immediately makes it obvious that your mind and body act independently from your will and awareness. As you progress it goes way past just being obvious. The main goal is essentially freeing your awareness and will from your mind and body's influence more and more. That's how you become free in this life. I don't now about the next though.

posts.com:
Angel numbers are normie bs and you should aim for more significant syncs. Jung describes synchronicities as events connected by an acausal principle instead of a causal one. The connection is psychology because the meaning is derived only from your perception of some connection.

I believe Jung assumed they were more common than they actually are because he was so prone to them. The best explanation I have found for why they might begin to happen to a person is because they are associated with "individuation"/bringing unconscious material to the forefront. I came to this conclusion from my own experiences and Jung obviously pioneered techniques for exploring your unconscious. As far as I've seen, they start happening if you're doing a good job. You can find a good description of this process if you read about Calcination, the first stage in psychology alchemy.

Jung also writes that they are the mechanism behind divination tools like tarot and astrology. I think they might also have something to do with "coming into contact with the ultimate reality" in a mystical sense.

If you start to get intense synchronicities, I recommend asking the universe for a follow up sync of a similar topic to prove the phenomenon to yourself beyond a reasonable doubt.

I'm talking to this Angel in the rain

She said goodbye in her way.
And I stood alone with nothing to say.

Like a rainbow but with a certain hue
And before me was the pen and paper
The only sound a hissing vapor
He watches me now always
A director watching his myriad plays
In that night I knew one truth
That demon was me, skin to biting tooth

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
That is the end of the many many poems and musings I have written this year inside of /ng/. It was more than I thought and the list spans this thread and the last.

I want to thank every Anon that inspired me. I do save a lot of your guys' stuff when the mood strikes me. This time however I thought it would be more appropriate to only post my own stuff.

There are many here that I have fought with and even more with which I have shared moments of relatable circumstances. We have discussed every topic, from physics to society and I can honestly say that I am grateful every day for each and every one of you.

There are many people missing these days but we have also gained many people. But to everyone I wish a Happy New Year and you have my thanks for being there for me in your own way throughout some desperate times in my life.

Here is a sonnet I like.

Some glory in their birth, some in their skill,
Some in their wealth, some in their body's force,
Some in their garments though new-fangled ill;
Some in their hawks and hounds, some in their horse;
And every humour hath his adjunct pleasure,
Wherein it finds a joy above the rest:
But these particulars are not my measure,
All these I better in one general best.
Thy love is better than high birth to me,
Richer than wealth, prouder than garments' cost,
Of more delight than hawks and horses be;
And having thee, of all men's pride I boast:
Wretched in this alone, that thou mayst take
All this away, and me most wretched make.

Happy New Year /ng/,
have a drink and be merry.
